headline: How Mark Kelly Gets Around This Self-Imposed Ban
author: Chuck Ross
sentences: Kelly, who has called corporate money "one of the biggest problems in our politics today," received $55,500 in contributions last quarter from the PACs of corporate trade groups and the Senate leadership committees of many of his fellow Democrats.

Rep. Ruben Gallego (D., Ariz.) criticized Kelly for raking in hundreds of thousands of dollars on the corporate speaking circuit, saying it conflicted with Kelly's self-imposed ban on corporate PAC contributions for his campaign.
Fund for the Majority PAC, the committee for Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D., Calif.), took $23,500 in contributions from Intel, Visa, and other corporations, while giving $5,000 to Kelly’s campaign.
The senator, who faces a tough reelection bid in November, introduced a bill with Sen. Jon Ossoff (D., Ga.) last month to ban companies from forming PACs or soliciting money to fund them.
Trade associations like the National Football League and Internet & Television Association also contributed to Kelly's campaign, according to his latest FEC disclosures.
It is funded by the executives of Comcast, Cox Communications, and Charter Communications, three of the biggest cable and broadband companies in the country.
In 2019, Kelly attended a fundraiser hosted by the firm lobbying for Citigroup, Chevron, and ExxonMobil even after he came out against corporate PAC money.
Sen. Mark Kelly (D., Ariz.) swore off corporate PAC contributions, but money from corporations is still finding a way into his campaign coffers.
Kelly took another $5,000 from the PAC for the Real Estate Roundtable, a trade group representing the country's biggest real estate developers.
Sen. Robert Menendez's (D., N.J.) New Millenium PAC took $92,500 from a variety of corporate PACs and trade groups and passed $2,500 to Kelly.
Kelly taking corporate donations through a loophole is the latest example of his inconsistent position on corporate influence in politics.
The PAC for the Association for Accessible Medicine, a trade group representing generic drug makers, gave another $2,000 to Kelly.
Amy Klobuchar (D., Minn.), Tammy Duckworth (D., Ill.), Richard Blumenthal (D., Conn.), Jack Reed (D., R.I.), and other Democrats.
"Our legislation would put an end to the corrupt influence of corporate PACs in our political system," Kelly said of the bill.
But while Kelly has not taken cash directly from corporate PACs, he has still benefited from their political contributions.
The leadership committees have received tens of thousands of dollars from the sort of corporate PACs that Kelly decries.
Kelly's campaign did not respond to questions about the loophole donations and whether he would refund them.
A review of FEC records shows all of the committees took thousands of dollars in corporate PAC money.
Eleven Democratic senators have given $40,000 to Kelly’s campaign through their leadership PACs.
Kelly also received contributions from three trade associations serving corporate interests.
The NFL's political action committee, Gridiron PAC, gave $2,500 to Kelly’s campaign.
The Internet & Television Association's PAC gave $5,000 to Kelly's campaign.
Kelly also received funds from the corporate-backed PACs of Sens.
The white-shoe law firm K&L Gates gave $1,000 to Kelly.
